metadata.title: Nanomaterials derived from metal–organic frameworks

sections.text:
The distinct crystalline and porous structures and tailored compositions of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) make them outstanding templates and precursors to create nanostructures by high-temperature pyro lysis. Many MOF-derived nanostructures have excellent chemical and mechanical stabilities, large specific surface areas, adjustable pore structures and various functionalities1. A timeline showing some of the breakthroughs in the study of the morphology, composition and application of MOF-derived nanostructures is shown in FIG. 1. In the first report of MOF-derived nanostructures, pristine carbons were synthesized by the thermal transformation of MOF precursors2. Subsequently, metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, metal phosphides, metal carbides and metal nanoparticles have been produced using MOFs as the starting materials3,4. Early studies also revealed that under the harsh and high-temperature conditions of pyrolysis, MOFs tend to collapse, and their original morphologies are damaged, leading to bulk materials with featureless morphologies2,5. More recently, by selecting appropriate MOF precursors and applying control strategies, this pyrolysis method has enabled the rational design of MOF-derived nanostructures with a range of morphologies. These MOF-derived nanostructures have shown great potential for applications such as gas storage and separation, sensing, catalysis, and energy storage and conversion6,7. The recognition of the importance of morphology in the enhancement of the performance of these nanomaterials in some of these applications has been the main driver of research in this field8,9. Compared with other synthetic approaches to produce nanostructures, the pyrolysis of MOFs, which have periodic crystalline structures and porosities, not only affords precise control of the size, shape, composition and structure but also allows the integration of diverse functionalities in one step10. Most synthetic methods to prepare nanostructures from MOF precursors involve a templating strategy and morphology-preserved transformations. In this regard, these MOF-templated strategies can be categorized into self-templating and external-templating methods. The self-templating method involves pyrolysis of MOF-only precursors, and the external-templating method uses MOF composites with external templates (for example, graphene, silica, carbon and metal oxides). Accordingly, a variety of MOF-derived nanostructures with diverse morphologies have been prepared, including 0D polyhedra, hollow and core–shell structures; 1D rods, hollow rods and tubes; 2D sheets, ribbons and sandwiches; and 3D arrays, frameworks and honeycomb-like structures11. Heteroatom-containing MOF precursors, such as nitrogen-rich zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), can be used to prepare nanostructures doped with hetero atoms (for example, nitrogen, sulfur, boron and phosphorus). However, it is challenging to fabricate these nanostructures with well-controlled structural characteristics that influence, or even determine, their electronic, physical and chemical properties14,15. Accordingly, controlling the morphologies of these nanostructures is an attractive way to regulate their properties.
In this Review, we focus on the morphological control and physico-chemical properties of MOF-derived nanostructures to enable optimization of their performance for applications such as sensing, catalysis, and energy storage and conversion. The relationship between the pristine structures of the MOF precursors and the interior and exterior morphologies of the derived nano structures is discussed.
0D nanostructures Nanoscale MOFs of controllable size and morphology can be strategically synthesized16,17. Upon pyrolysis, these well-defined MOF precursors chemically transform, while their original morphologies are preserved, to give MOF-derived nanostructures with polyhedral, hollow and core–shell shapes18,19. To achieve morphology-preserved thermal transformation, the MOF precursors must be sufficiently thermally stable20,21 because thermally un stable frameworks collapse below their conversion temperatures. For example, ZIFs with high thermal stabilities, up to 550 °C in N2 (REF. 22), can be thermally converted to nanostructures without distortion of their original morphology23. The resultant nanostructures include carbons, oxides, sulfides and phosphides, and they can be subsequently doped, in a uniform manner, with heteroatoms and metals24.

sections.heading: Polyhedra
sections.text:
One of the most representative morphologies of MOFderived nanostructures are polyhedra (for example, hexahedral, octahedral and dodecahedral structures) with hierarchical porosities and large surface areas. The thermal treatment of MOF precursors, like ZIFs,
which have many edges and corners, can generate nanostructures with numerous accessible active sites25. These highly disperse active sites embedded in a carbon matrix with high electrical conductivity, as well as the interconnected pores, facilitate mass transport and promote the catalytic activity and stability of the nanostructures for electrocatalysis, such as the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). In this regard, the selection of the porous precursor is important for the preparation of nanostructures with large surface areas and hierarchical porosities. These features are also essential for good performance as supercapacitors and electrocatalysts owing to the effects on mass transfer and diffusion processes26.
Rational design of the architecture and composition of the precursor is required to generate the desired nanostructure20. More specifically, the incorporation of doping heteroatoms (for example, N, S, B, P, Co and Fe) in the MOFs, enables the electronic properties and conductivities of the resultant materials to be tuned. In addition, MOFs with predetermined components, such as Zn–Co–MOFs, can act as precursors and produce porous carbons with Co atoms embedded within the carbon11. The control of the pyrolysis temperature and the ratio of Zn to Co components are crucial for the formation of single Co atoms27. However, precise control over the structure of single metal atoms, such as dispersion and binding mode, is still difficult, and achieving a relatively high content of single atoms on carbons remains challenging28. Bimetallic ZIFs (containing both ZIF-8 and ZIF-67) produce porous carbon polyhedra, which integrate the advantages of the high surface area and high nitrogen content of ZIF-8 and the high degree of graphitization of ZIF-67 (REF. 29). Moreover, the regular pores of MOF precursors control the small sizes of in situ-generated nanoparticles, which are uniformly distributed and confined in the pores, and also prevent agglomeration of the nanoparticles during pyrolysis30. Other approaches to protect MOF precursors have been applied to prevent aggregation during pyrolysis31,32. sections.heading: Hollow nanostructures
sections.text:
Hollow nanomaterials have larger surface areas, lower densities and higher loading capacities than their solid counterparts36–38. The external-templating strategy, which uses removable or sacrificial templates, is considered the most straightforward approach to make hollow nanostructures39,40 (FIG. 2a). Typically, polystyrene and silica are used as external templates and are first coated with a layer of MOF. Subsequent pyrolysis of the templated MOF and etching result in hollow structures with a void size and shape that are highly dependent on the template and a shell thickness that mainly relies on the coating procedure41,42. However, preliminary surface modification of the external templates, usually by functionalization of carboxyl groups, is required at the beginning of this strategy. Also, the external template must be removed at the end of the process. These tedious and complicated procedures lead to low reproducibility and high cost, restricting the use of this strategy.
A second templating method — self-templating — makes hollow nanostructures without an external template, thus reducing the cost and simplifying the synthesis43,44. In this method, the controlled synthesis of the MOF precursors (for example, Zn-, Co-, Cu-, Niand Mn-containing MOFs) is crucial45,46. Dodecahedral ZIF-67 is a MOF that is commonly used to create hollow
MOF-derived nanostructures47,48. It is believed that volume loss and internal gas release are responsible for producing hollow architectures with high surface areas49. Hollow nanostructures have promising applications in lithium-ion batteries because of the improvement in Li-diffusion kinetics and cycling stability enabled by the nanostructures. More specifically, the hollow interiors of nanostructures not only allow easy access for Li+ ions and reduce their diffusion paths but also provide additional free volume to alleviate the structural strain associated with the repeated Li-ion insertion-extraction process50 (TABLE 1). Bimetallic MOF precursors with an appropriate ratio of two metals can also produce hollow nanostructures51. In hierarchical structures composed of multilevel hollow sections, the material benefits from having many chemical compositions and compartments, thus improving the catalytic activity and cycling stability for catalysis52 (TABLE 1).

sections.heading: Core−shell nanostructures
sections.text:
Strong synergistic effects between the core and the shell components can endow core–shell nanostructures with good stability, functionality and dispersibility53. Generally, these nanostructures are synthesized by the thermal treatment of predesigned core–shell MOF precursors54,55 (FIG. 2b). The self-templating method can also produce core–shell nanostructures by carefully regulating the pyrolysis process of MOF particles56,57. Ostwald ripening has been used to explain the formation of core– shell nanostructures58; however, thorough mechanistic studies are required to fully understand the construction of the structures. In particular, the in situ formation of uniform carbon shells on metal oxides during pyrolysis can enhance the electrical conductivity, which facilitates electron transportation and accommodates the volume changes of the metal-oxide nanoparticles by forming robust and stable solid–electrolyte interface layers when applied to lithium-ion batteries58.

Multi-shell nanostructures typically have enhanced properties — including electrocatalytic activity, capacity and cycling stability — compared with their single-shell counterparts as a consequence of their increased structural robustness and the presence of hierarchical pores that modulate volume expansion and increase long-term stability59,60. In a multi-shell structure, the internal shell acts as the active centre to accelerate catalysis, and the external permeable shells act as nanoreactors to prevent deactivation of the catalyst61,62.
Achieving morphological homogeneity, efficiency and scalable production are remaining challenges in the synthesis of MOF-derived nanostructures. Although large surface areas can be achieved in MOF-derived carbon polyhedra, strict tailoring of the porosity is difficult. The sizes of MOF-derived hollow nanostructures are typically larger than 200 nm, which is not ideal for some applications. For example, the low density of the nanostructures results in a low volumetric capacitance for energy storage applications. Therefore, an appropriate void ratio is required in such hollow structures to optimize the performance in different applications. The self-templating method has advantages for the direct conversion from MOFs to core–shell and hollow nanostructures; however, it works for only a few MOFs. Studies on complex multi-shell nanostructures have been largely limited to metal oxides; future research should expand to other types, such as sulfides and phosphides. Finally, the mechanism for the formation of complex nanostructures by controlling the core, intershell spacing, and the size, number and composition of the shell, remains to be fully investigated.

sections.heading: 1D nanostructures
sections.text:
1D nanomaterials, such as nanorods and nanotubes, share certain characteristics with 0D nanoparticles and 2D nanosheets, including large surface areas and quantum confinement effects63,64. Their mechanical, electronic, optical and porous properties are different from those of bulk materials, making them a focus of research in the fabrication of optical, electronic, optoelectronic and electrochemical devices65–67.
Both self-templating and external-templating are strategies to produce 1D MOF-derived nano materials68–70 (FIG. 3a). In general, rod-like MOF precursors are typically used to produce corresponding 1D nanostructures via self-templating morphology-preserved thermal transformation. However, there are only a few 1D MOF precursors available for the self-templating synthesis. Alternatively, the external-templating method can be used with various MOFs and templates to produce uniform nanorods. However, additional surface modification of the external templates, usually with carboxyl groups, complicates the synthetic procedure and limits the capacity for scale-up. Moreover, post-synthesis removal of the external templates may damage the templated nanostructures. 1D tubular nanostructures are commonly produced from Fe-, Co- or Ni-containing MOFs or their nanocomposites, with the assistance of catalytic effects of metal nanoparticles formed in situ71. Their morphological characteristics, structural properties and ease of fabrication make 1D nanostructures
advantageous for several applications. For example, their high surface-to-volume ratio and the uniform encapsulation of highly active species, such as metal nanoparticles and heteroatoms, facilitates fast mass diffusion to participate in surface reactions and hence makes them attractive for sensing applications.

sections.heading: Nanorods
sections.text:
Rod-like nanostructures are synthesized from MOF nanorod precursors using a self-templating method72,73. Bimetallic and multi-metallic MOF precursors can generate 1D nanorods with tuneable compositions and uniform distributions of active species in a highintegrity structure. For example, mesoporous ternary NixCo3 − xO4 nanorods were prepared from bimetallic Co–Ni–MOF-74 nanorods using the self-templating method. The mesoporous structure and rod-like shape of the NixCo3 − xO4 nanorods shorten the pathway for ion and electron transport, which together with their various active components, guarantees high performance in lithium-ion batteries74 (TABLE 1). Interestingly, Al–MOFs can produce carbon nanorods with a spongy structure containing interconnected carbon layers75. The materials comprising spongy carbon nanorods have a higher surface area and a larger pore volume than those of nanorods without a spongy structure and show superior sensing capabilities towards toxic aromatic compounds. It is noteworthy that a higher pyrolysis temperature promotes the formation of an ordered graphitic structure of carbon, which enhances the electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance for electrocatalysis. However, high temperatures may also result in partial decomposition and, in some cases, complete collapse of the porous structures. In this regard, an optimized pyrolysis temperature to achieve a good balance of electrical conductivity, structural porosity and density of active species is essential for enhancing the overall performance.
The external-templating method is another route to 1D MOF-derived nanostructures. For example, TiO2 whiskers, can be used as external templates to prepare TiO2@MOF nanocomposites. Thermal treatment of the composite precursors produces TiO2@CuO nanorods with highly active CuO nanoparticles on the surface76. The size, dispersion and loading of the active nanoparticles can be tuned by controlling the thickness of the MOF shell on the templates. In another study, electrospun Pd-loaded ZIF-8 nanofibres are transformed to Pd@ZnO embedded WO3 nanofibres by pyrolysis77. The rod-like shape and various active components make these Pd@ZnO–WO3 nanofibres useful for sensing toluene gas with good sensitivity, response time and selectivity (TABLE 2). Additionally, reduction in the radial and axial lengths of nanorods will enhance the quantum size effect and is likely to improve the sensing performance in future studies. Moreover, the agglomeration of active nanoparticles during hightemperature pyrolysis can be compensated by appropriate external templates that stabilize and disperse the active sites at high loadings and promote catalytic activity78.

The subsequent annealing produces external-templated 1D hollow nanostructures. The benefits of abundant active species on the surface and the hollow structure decrease the diffusion pathways and relieve the volume expansion during the electrochemical process79. Furthermore, complex hollow structures with multilevel architectures, such as multilayered shells or multiple channels, have been made. Hollow 1D nanostructures with abundant active sites on their surfaces have short diffusion distances for ions, and the direct contact between the active sites and the electrolyte enables rapid charge transfer. Moreover, the voids within multilevel hollow structures effectively reduce the volume expansion during the electrochemical process compared with the single-shelled hollow counterpart, boost the catalytic reaction and maintain the overall stability with electrochemical capacities superior to those of many other structured materials80.
The construction of 1D hollow nanostructures usually requires multistep syntheses. Effective and universal construction routes are needed to produce diverse multi-layer and multi-component hollow nanostructures. Moreover, the specific influences of multi-shelled structures relative to their single-shelled counterparts on the final performance needs to be further elucidated. It will also be helpful to develop theoretical guidelines for the construction of complex hierarchical architectures.

sections.heading: Nanotubes
sections.text:
Nanotubes, especially carbon nanotubes (CNTs), have features, including high surface area, mechanical strength and flexibility, that facilitate electron and ion transport81. The external-templating method is considered to be a straightforward and versatile route to making nanotubes. For example, ultrathin Te nanowires act as external templates for preparing Te@ZIF-8, and
subsequent pyrolysis results in the formation of hollow carbon nanofibres82. An alternative approach is the catalytic growth of CNTs with Fe group metals83,84. More specifically, Fe-, Co-, or Ni-containing MOFs or MOFcontaining composites can be self-templated to produce tubular nanostructures as a consequence of the in situ generation of catalytically active metallic nanoparticles during carbonization85,86 (FIG. 3b).
Under certain catalytic conditions, MOFs encapsulating nitrogen-containing molecules, such as dicyan diamide, can produce bamboo-like CNTs with homogeneously encapsulated nitrogen atoms. Moreover, the presence of dicyandiamide induces a graphitic structure and promotes the formation of CNTs at low temperatures (below 700 °C)87. Bamboo-like CNTs have more graphitic edges and active sites than straight nanotubes and, as a result, have enhanced electron transfer and electro catalytic performance. The nitrogen content, doping state and diameter of the CNTs can be easily controlled by the amount of dicyandiamide88. The encapsulation of heteroatoms and defects in CNTs also enables the anchoring of the metal nanoparticles or other active species, thus improving the catalytic activity89. Chemical vapour deposition (CVD) is a common route for the mass production of CNTs with controlled nanostructures. Compared with CVD, the self- templating method enables the straight forward production of CNTs from MOFs without the need for expensive and complicated instruments and additional tedious treatments. However, CVD can produce both single-walled CNTs and multi-walled CNTs with high-quality graphitization and diverse hetero atom doping, while the self-templating method usually produces nitrogen-doped multi-walled CNTs81,88,89. Moreover, precise control over the location and the distribution of doped heteroatoms in MOF-templated CNTs remains a challenge. Effective control of the diameter and length, as well as a higher degree of graphitization, is also anti cipated to improve the properties of CNTs made using a MOF template.

sections.heading: 2D nanostructures
sections.text:
The large surface areas of 2D nanomaterials (for example, nanosheets, nanoplates, nanoflakes and nanofilms) allow guest molecules to reach abundant and exposed active sites, making the nanomaterials attractive for applications in electronics, energy conversion and storage, and gas separation90–93. MOF-derived 2D nanostructures are prepared by template-directed methods, specifically, either by a self-templating method, which is simple and efficient69,94, or by an external- templating method, which combines the characteristics of the MOF-derived components and templates95,96. Self-templating 2D nanostructures To make 2D nanostructures by the self-templating method, MOFs with lamellar morphologies are used as starting materials97 (FIG. 4a). The pyrolysis conditions, such as temperature and gas atmosphere, modulate the composition of the derived nanostructures98,99. The self-templating method combined with an exfoliation approach has been used to prepare few-layered graphene nanoribbons, in which 1D carbon nanorods are prepared by the morphology-preserved thermal transformation of rod-shaped MOFs, followed by the exfoliation of the activated self-templated carbon nanorods70 (FIG. 4b).

To explore the applications of 2D nanostructures, MOFtemplated anatase TiO2 nanoplates have been used as both catalyst support and photoreductant to produce core–shell Pt@Rh nanoparticles100. The ultra-small and uniform size of Pt@Rh nanoparticles and the strong metal–support interactions endow the Pt@Rh-embedded TiO2 nanoplates with excellent catalytic activity for the hydrolytic dehydrogenation of ammonia borane (TABLE 2). Compared with the bulk structures, the surfaces of MOFtemplated lamellar nanostructures have abundant accessible active sites, which can efficiently facilitate reactant diffusion and accelerate catalytic reactions101,102.
The self-templating method enables the production of 2D nanostructures with the controlled incorporation of active species, including metal nanoparticles and hetero atoms. A good distribution of these active species is important to boost the catalytic activity. In particular, it is difficult to stabilize highly active single-metal-atom catalysts on the supports during pyrolysis28. The annealing temperature and metal composition of the MOF precursor are the parameters that most strongly affect the production of single metal atoms and thus need to be carefully controlled. Furthermore, the preparation of few-layered graphene nanosheets from MOFs has been achieved70, but high-yield single-layered graphene with high crystallinity and large lateral size is still being pursued. Therefore, improved fabrication strategies for 2D MOF-derived nanostructures are necessary.
External-templating 2D nanostructures The challenges in constructing high-quality 2D MOFs can be mitigated by using 2D external templates (for example, graphene) to prepare template@MOF composites, which can be pyrolysed to form 2D nanostructures103. This external-templating method integrates the properties of both the template and the MOF to improve the performance of the product compared with that of each reactant104. Graphene, with excellent electrical conductivity, is one of the most popular templates for deriving 2D nanomaterials105. Accordingly, sandwich-
like nano materials in the form of MDN@Graphene@ MDN (where MDN is a MOF-derived nanostructure, including carbons, metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, metal phosphides and metal nanoparticles) are produced from predesigned MOF@Graphene oxide@MOF composites106,107. In some cases, surfactants, such as poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP), are introduced to assist the in situ growth of MOFs on graphene oxide for composite construction108,109. Alternatively, layered double hydroxides (LDHs), which have unsaturated coordinated metal cations on their surface, can form MOF@LDH@ MOF composites, from which corresponding MDN@ LDH@MDN sandwich-like materials are produced110,111. External-templated 2D nanostructures have good electrical conductivity, stable interconnected networks and abundant exposed active species to promote catalytic processes112.
Most external-templating studies are focused on in situ growth of MOF on the surface of the template; however, the challenge in this process is the formation of a uniform layer of MOF with a controlled thickness on the 2D-structured templates. The requirements for organic solvents or polymer surfactants and additional postsynthesis treatment complicate this method. The relationships between the structures and compositions of the MOF-containing precursors and the structures and properties of the resulting derivatives should be investigated. In addition, maximizing the density of the exposed active sites and controlling their distributions would enhance electronic and mass transport, further promoting catalytic activity. The range of external templates that assemble with MOFs must diversify to yield a larger library of 2D nanostructures.

By means of rationally designed MOF precursors, the derived nanostructures can be engineered with chemically and morphologically desirable functionalities114. 3D nanostructures, such as arrays, flowers, honeycombs, foams and sponges, have been realized through controllable synthetic approaches115,116. Nanowire arrays are commonly prepared by the pyrolysis of MOFs on flexible conductive substrates117. In addition, 1D nanomaterials, for example, CNTs and metal-oxide nanowires, can be knitted together or assembled to form MOF-containing nanocomposites, which upon thermal treatment, lead to nano materialtemplated 3D frameworks118. Other 3D nanostructures are made from MOFs or MOF composites through external-templating or self-templating methods119.

sections.heading: Arrays
sections.text:
Well-aligned nanowire arrays with catalytic components can be prepared by carbonization of MOFs grown on 2D flexible conductive substrates, such as copper and aluminium foils (FIG. 5a). For example, porous Co3O4– carbon nanowire arrays are prepared by carbonization of ZIF-67 grown on copper foil120. These arrays can be used as catalysts or as electrodes in energy storage devices because of the strong attachment between the arrays and the substrates as well as the active sites already present on the surface of the arrays. MOF arrays composed of different metal ions can be thermally converted to homogeneous multi-metallic nanoarrays with uniform dispersion of metal components on the surface and the interface121. In addition, 3D flexible substrates (such as nickel foams, carbon supports and conducting polymers) with good mechanical strength, high conductivity, excellent corrosion resistance and commercial availability are promising templates122. In another study, ZnO nanorod arrays on a carbon cloth were used as a template to grow ZIF-8 and hence produce ZnO@ ZIF-8 arrays supported on the cloth. The pyrolysis of ZnO@ZIF-8 results in the formation of a shell comprising an amorphous carbon framework with ZnO quantum dots encapsulated within the framework and a core composed of ZnO nanorods123. In this hybrid material, the adhesive force between the framework and the ZnO nanorods is stronger than that of other carbon-coating methods124. Core–shell nanostructure arrays with multifunctional components provide accessible active sites, short ion-transport pathways and high conductivity, thus promoting the electrochemical properties125.
In contrast to conventional supported metaloxide nanoarrays, the thermal conversion of a MOF to a multi-component array supported on a substrate allows in situ integration of multiple components, leading to stronger attachments between the components and facilitating high electrical conductivity and charge transfer capability. Moreover, the direct attachment of nanostructures to substrates without additional binders favours fast mass and charge transport and high structural stability, which are necessary for good cycling performance. The MOF-templated strategy also produces highly ordered hierarchical porous nanostructures with large active areas. The exploration of synthetic methods
for the construction of MOF nanoarrays on conductive substrates remains a goal of future research. Developing predesigned nanoarrays with multilevel structures and multiple compositions can be promoted by control of the thermolysis process.

sections.heading: 1D nanomaterial-crosslinked 3D frameworks
sections.text:
1D nanomaterials, typically CNTs and metal-oxide nanowires, can be used to make crosslinked 3D networks126. These 3D networks comprise MOF-derived nanoparticles as the nodes and 1D nanomaterials as the linkers and can be prepared by pyrolysis of MOFs with embedded nanomaterials. The introduction of conductive carbons, for example, CNTs, into MOFs, crosslinks the MOF nanocrystals and increases the conductivity of the resultant materials127 (FIG. 5b). The combination of the good capacity and catalytic ability of the MOF-derived nanomaterials and the mechanical and chemical stability of CNTs endows the framework with increased electrical conductivity and accelerated mass transport compared with those of individual MOFs without CNTs128.
1D metal-oxide nanowires, such as CeO2, with remarkable reversible surface redox reactions for cataly sis, have been used to create continuous, crosslinked frameworks composed of metal-oxide nanowires129. The strong chemical interactions between the metal-oxide templates and the MOF-derived compositions in hierarchical networks leads to their good catalytic properties130.
The ratio of MOFs to 1D nanomaterials in the precursors influences the stability of crosslinked frameworks, while the size and shape of MOFs and 1D nanomaterials are important for optimizing the overall catalytic properties. Moreover, the interface areas and corresponding interactions between MOFs and 1D nanomaterials have strong influences on the catalytic process, such as the adsorption–desorption rate of the substrate molecules and the stability of the intermediate state130.
Other 3D nanostructures The range of 3D MOF-derived nanomaterials made by self-templating and external-templating methods includes but is not limited to flowers, starfishes, honeycombs, foams and sponges131,132. A variety of templates, including nickel foams, polymer sponges, graphitized carbon frameworks and carbon cloths, have been used to create MOF-templated nanocomposites. Subsequent thermal treatment of these nanocomposites leads to 3D nanostructures133. The nanostructures can be chemically and morphologically engineered by the rational design of hybrid precursors. For example, iron-containing MOFs can produce 3D porous carbon with magnetic nanoparticles encapsulated within the porous structure — this arrangement is particularly attractive for oil adsorption and oil–water separation processes134,135. The use of conductive external templates further increases the electrical conductivity of the nanostructures and enables active species on the surface of the MOF-derived nanostructure to participate in electrochemical reactions136. Another intriguing feature of external-templated 3D nano structures is the effective interaction between MOF-derived nanomaterials and templates, enabling their direct use as electrochemical devices without additional binders138.
In addition to the external-templating method, MOFs can be used as sacrificial templates for self-templated 3D nanostructures during their thermal decomposition139,140. For example, N, S dual-doped honeycomb-like porous carbons immobilized with cobalt sulfide nanoparticles have been produced from an aluminium-based MIL-101-NH2 composite141 (FIG. 5c). The secondary precursors, thiourea and CoCl2 encapsulated in the MOF pores, not only generate a uniform distribution of Co9S8 nanoparticles within the carbon nanostructures but also lead to unique honeycomb porous architectures through a guest-induced morphology control process. This honeycomb-like structure facilitates the exposure of active Co9S8 nanoparticles to the electrolyte and shortens their diffusion length, promoting the overall electrochemical activity and stability.
Despite the progress being made in the selftemplating method, an insufficient understanding of
the formation mechanism of the 3D nanostructures is a bottleneck in the realization of optimized structures and performance. Spectroscopic and electrochemical studies are needed to follow the structural evolution of self-templating nano structures during morphological transformation.

sections.heading: Future perspective
sections.text:
The unlimited combinations of metal ions and organic ligands in MOF precursors leads to a diverse range of possible nanostructures. In the past few years, the morphology of these nanostructures has been increasingly controllable and has had a noticeable influence on certain physical and chemical properties11. MOF-templated methods have enabled the synthesis of high-performance nanomaterials with tuneable properties (TABLES 1,2). However, the complex synthetic procedures and the high cost of MOF precursors limits the economic viability of the products. More types of MOFs, other than the wellknown ones such as MOF-5, ZIFs and MILs, are desired in the synthesis.
The morphology of MOF-derived nanostructures can be tuned by using the external-templating method. However, external templates are expensive and require

By contrast, the selftemplating method is a facile and economical method to generate MOF-derived nanostructures, but it lacks control of morphological features, such as size and porosity. More versatile preparative methods with greater intentional control of the morphology are desired. In particular, the factors that determine the morphology of the derived nanostructures, such as MOF precursors (component and structure), pyrolysis conditions (temperature, gas atmosphere, time and rate of heating) and the introduction of guest components, should be systematically investigated. Furthermore, complex hierarchical nanostructures with multilevel structures and many components should be synthesized because of the co operation from multilevel layers and multiple components, which can greatly enhance catalytic activity, structural stability and electrical conductivity.
The incorporation of heteroatoms and metal-based species, with the content and distribution of these species dependent on the MOF precursor and synthetic strategy, is important for improving the properties of the resultant nanomaterials. For example, abundant defects introduced to amorphous carbon through controlled synthesis generally improve the catalytic activity56,80. Currently, the synthesis of heteroatom-doped nanostructures is mostly limited to the ZIF series. MOFs with abundant heteroatoms, other than ZIFs, and doping strategies must be developed to precisely control the dopant content, type and distribution. MOFs with multiple metal centres and/or multiple ligand linkers are ideal candidates for this purpose. Alternatively, combining MOFs with secondary heteroatom-rich and/or metalrich precursors to form nanocomposites is an effective way to achieve fine control of the compositions and thus performance of these materials. The elucidation of the specific roles of active species in the catalytic process also requires further experimental investigation.
The morphology, including the size, shape, composition and structure, of MOF-derived nano structures is crucial for their performance; therefore, more investigations are expected to study the morphological transformation during pyrolysis. Measurements, such as thermogravimetric analysis and electrochemical and spectroscopic tests, may reveal the underlying mechanisms. Furthermore, a better understanding of the structure–property relationship will guide the design and development of MOF-derived materials.
The large surface areas, hierarchical pores and good stabilities of MOF-derived nanostructures are also promising for biomedical uses32. For example, fluorescent carbon nanodots142, which can be produced directly from MOFs, are attractive for bioimaging and biosensing applications. Additionally, the rational design and synthesis of MOF-derived nanostructures may be beneficial for the construction and performance of flexible and portable electronic and sensing devices. Finally, if chiral nanostructures could be made by MOF-templating, the nanostructures could provide a promising nanoscale environment for chiral recognition and separation.
We anticipate that other assembled materials, such as covalent organic frameworks and hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks, will be promising starting materials for the fabrication of similar nanostructures143. Covalent organic frameworks, with complete organic skeletons, provide great opportunities to facilely construct porous carbon and to precisely control the heteroatom distribution144,145.
In summary, the MOF-templated strategy provides a promising opportunity to produce a variety of nanostructures. Engineering the morphologies, structures and properties of the MOF-derived nanostructures is helpful to improve their performance. Continued research and development should focus on the deeper investigation of MOF-derived nanostructures and the understanding of the underlying mechanisms to make this strategy more convincing and versatile.

metadata.abstractText: | The thermal transformation of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) generates a variety of nanostructured materials, including carbon-based materials, metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, metal phosphides and metal carbides. These derivatives of MOFs have characteristics such as high surface areas, permanent porosities and controllable functionalities that enable their good performance in sensing, gas storage, catalysis and energy-related applications. Although progress has been made to tune the morphologies of MOF-derived structures at the nanometre scale, it remains crucial to further our knowledge of the relationship between morphology and performance. In this Review, we summarize the synthetic strategies and optimized methods that enable control over the size, morphology, composition and structure of the derived nanomaterials. In addition, we compare the performance of materials prepared by the MOF-templated strategy and other synthetic methods. Our aim is to reveal the relationship between the morphology and the physico-chemical properties of MOF-derived nanostructures to optimize their performance for applications such as sensing, catalysis, and energy storage and conversion.
